conclusion: Analyzing what happens to shadows A, B, C, and D when the light source moves backward.
The image shows a black glove, a small black notebook or card holder with rings, a black hat with a brim, and a yellow/orange peach above slabs with shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
Shadow A appears to be from the hat, shadow B from the glove, shadow C from the peach, and shadow D from the notebook/card holder.
When a light source illuminates an object, the shadow forms in the area where light is blocked.
As light moves backward, shadows shift closer to being directly beneath their respective objects.
As light moves backward, shadows become smaller and more defined (less diffuse).
Shadow A (hat shadow) is currently elongated and displaced from directly beneath the hat.

When light moves backward, shadow B will move closer to being directly beneath the glove.

When a light source is close to objects, it creates larger, more spread-out shadows that extend further from the objects.
As the light source moves farther away, its rays become more parallel (less divergent).
Parallel light rays create shadows that are closer to the same size as the objects and positioned more directly beneath them.
When the light source moves backward, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move closer to being directly beneath their respective objects.
